13 other unreasonably simple habits to change your life:

1. Waking up at 5:45am solves 99.9% of daily issues.

2. Grab your to-do list. Do the thing you want to do least, first.

3. Stop all 60 min meetings, make them 45 minutes. Tighter meetings, more time.

4. No social media, email, or text when you wake up. Write something, read something, or create something before you get sucked in.

5. Do the $1,000/hr Test. Group work in 3 buckets based on return: $10, $100, $1,000. Offload one low ROI task per day.

6. Change one meeting a week to a walking call. Watch how excited the other meeting member becomes.

7. Add a How vs Won't check-in. When you say, "that WON'T work." Instead ask, "How could that work?"

8. Be the dumbest one in your friend group, then move on when you‚Äôre not. As they say, if you‚Äôre the smartest person in the room, you‚Äôre in the wrong room.

9. Take a picture of your net worth. What gets measured gets managed. Check finances daily.

10. Always the stairs, never the elevator. Pick the hard option. See how much stronger you are than you think.

11. Never write to-dos in stone. You're 10x more productive if you reprioritize daily.

12. Meditate. 10 minutes a day. For a twofer - do it in the sauna. Sometimes hacking culture gets it right.

13. Get intimidated. Everything you want is on the other side of fear. Do something every day that scares you a little bit.

Life is the small things repeated daily.

Change one daily habit, and beautiful things start to happen...

So pick one.

full_text:
I‚Äôm 39.

27 lessons I wish I learned in my 20s: 

1. As soon as you hit your 30s, you‚Äôll understand... Your 20s actually suck. If you feel like it sucks right now, guess what? It‚Äôs supposed to. It gets better.

2. Your first job is like the DMV. Awful. Everyone‚Äôs mad. Nothing works. But the key is.. You are not supposed to stay there.

3. It is very hard to change the world when you are broke. So don't apologize for chasing money.

4. Meet everyone. Say yes to everything. You narrow the field later.

5. Do it all. Because you‚Äôll die eventually and life will make you slow down. But up until then, eat the world.

6. You are not everyone‚Äôs cup of tea, that‚Äôs a good thing.

7. The most lucrative things you can do in your 20s: 1) learn how to invest, 2) apprentice in PE, real estate, or venture.

8. If they‚Äôre not interesting when you‚Äôre sober, don‚Äôt drink until they become it.

9. Never buy to impress. Being wealthy > looking wealthy‚Ä¶ even when that first big-kid check hits your bank account.

10. The most important question you can ask yourself often: Does this bring joy?

11. Do favors, don‚Äôt take them. There‚Äôs often a hidden price.

12. If I was in my 20s, I‚Äôd try to work for one type of company‚Ä¶ One where they reward outcomes not hours. Winning > running really hard for a really long time.

13. Seed is only as good as its soil. Where you live during your 20s matters. Take some time away from your hometown.

14. If you feel cynical about the world‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt blame you. But always remember the number one superpower for your generation is HOPE.

15. If you‚Äôre prone to loneliness and isolation.. do NOT work a remote job. A small team with sleepless nights and shared goals is a powerful thing.

16. Touch grass. A walk outside will be better for your brain than anything you find on your phone.

17. Burnout doesn‚Äôt come from working too hard. Burnout comes from working too hard, on things that don‚Äôt light you up.

18. Learn how to save now, but understand that saving isn‚Äôt what makes you rich.

19. If you want to make more money, be more useful to people who have more money.

20. You must learn to be disliked or you will find yourself stuck in a prison of other people's beliefs.

21. Most successful people I've met aren't that smart. They move fast, they take risk, they work a lot. That's it.

22. If old you doesn‚Äôt make you cringe, you haven‚Äôt grown enough.

23. Do something hard every day. Then watch that ‚Äúsomething‚Äù evolve as you become stronger and stronger.

24. If you haven‚Äôt done it, you just have an opinion.

25. Marrying well is the biggest life hack of all. Marrying poorly is a costly path to misery. Choose wisely.

26. Working smarter not harder is a beautiful lie. You will not know how to work smart until you've worked very hard for an irrationally long time.

27. Take notes from old people‚Ä¶ Waking up early, being married, reading books, going to bed at 10pm, and drinking less is actually amazing.

There‚Äôs no such thing as the right or wrong business.

There‚Äôs only the business that‚Äôs right or wrong for you.

One of the most common DMs I get is:

"Should I buy a laundromat, car wash, or storage units?"

But that's totally the wrong question to begin with...because everyone has different goals.

That‚Äôs why I created the Contrarian Deal Clarity Framework to help first time owners buy a biz.

You need to define 5 components:

1. Your Ideal Owner Experience

Saying ‚ÄúI want to leave my 9-5‚Äù is too wishy-washy.

To trade in your W2 form, your vision board needs to be specific on three things:

- Personal goals (do you want more family time or grind for yourself)
- Income goals (replace your $75k salary or build an empire)
- Business goals (be a hands-on operator or absentee owner)

2. Your Zone of Genius

Think of this as the intersection between:

- Passion (what you love)
- Skills & Experience (what you‚Äôre good at)
- Network (who you know)

Most people ignore this and buy businesses they eventually hate running.

Don‚Äôt be most people.

3. Business Size

It‚Äôs easy to fantasize about buying a Fortune 500 company.

But we‚Äôre not playing the billionaire game here.

As a first-time time buyer, look for micro acquisitions:

- <$1M cost
- $50K-$200K profits
- 1-3X multiples

Less competition, more opportunity, fewer headaches.

4. Profit

Remember...you‚Äôre not just buying a business for the sake of it.

‚Ä¢ for lower acquisition costs

2. Auto-renewal subscriptions

6. Simple consumables

These are one-off items that are repurchased out of sheer habit & loyalty. Think, regulars at coffee shops, your favorite brand of toothpaste, transportation you have to take every day.

Why you never get what you want...

- You don‚Äôt ask.

- You don‚Äôt know when to walk away.

Here's how to avoid these negotiation mistakes (& get the deal you deserve):

If you want to fail in negotiating and alway overpay... don‚Äôt read this.

Buyers with experience only negotiate on three variables that determine the value of a business.

Most sellers don't even understand these concepts, which gives you a massive advantage if you can educate them on how deals really work:

1. EBITDA/SDE

Contrary to popular belief, this isn't about the number on their P&L.

It's about the cash flow you‚Äôll actually get when you take over.

Here‚Äôs an example:

If a seller says "we made $500k last year" but half of that came from a one-time contract that won't renew‚Ä¶

You can't pay for income that won't exist for you.

That's like buying a house and paying for the furniture they're taking with them.

Most buyers get destroyed here because they don't adjust for:

- Salary to replace owner
- Revenue concentration risks
- One-time events that won't repeat
- Expenses that will increase under new ownership

2. Multiple

Think of this as a direct reflection of risk.

Everything that increases risk lowers the multiple. Everything that decreases risk raises it.

That‚Äôs why some businesses trade at 15x while others struggle to get 2x.

Lower multiples come from:

- Revenue trending downward
- Business depends entirely on the seller
- Messy financials
- High employee turnover

These are red flags screaming "this could fall apart tomorrow."

Conversely, higher multiples come from the opposite:

- Documented systems and processes
- Diversified revenue streams
- Strong management team
- Clean books
- Consistent YOY growth

You can‚Äôt negotiate the multiple arbitrarily. It‚Äôs calculated with hard numbers.

But you can influence it by identifying and addressing the risks contractually rather than just pushing for a lower price.

You're buying the future but paying for the past.

The multiple reflects how confident you are in that future.

3. Terms

Price is what you pay, terms are how you pay.

You can give a seller their price IF you get your terms. Or you can give them their terms if you get your price.

But you CAN‚ÄôT give them both.

It‚Äôs the law of price and terms:

Terms are how you hedge against every risk you identified in the deal. For example:

- If there‚Äôs key employee risk ‚Üí Add retention bonuses to the deal
- Seller wants higher valuation? ‚Üí Use seller financing
- Documentation not in place? ‚Üí Long transition and training period

The idea is to use the contract to protect against your biggest fears.

At the end of the day, negotiation isn‚Äôt about winning.

It‚Äôs about getting what you want while keeping the other side happy enough that they don‚Äôt sabotage the deal.

Own a two bed apartment and work from home? 

Your W2 friends have to pay full rent, but as a biz owner?

2. The $10M QSBS Advantage 

Most people pay 20%+ on investment gains.

But with a qualifying C-Corp, QSBS can exclude $15M tax-free (with rules).

4. The S-Corp Split

Earn $100K+ outside of a W-2?

Setting up an S-Corp lets you split income into salary + distributions.

When you're self-employed, you have (up to) 15.3% payroll taxes on your income. With an S-Corp, you have no payroll taxes on your business owner income.

Reasonable salary still apply but this structure can lower self-employment taxes.

5. The 20% QBI Deduction

That means your business needs to be operating as either a:

Qualified business income is the net amount of a business' income, with a few exceptions (investment income, income from business outside US, certain interest income, etc). 

Helps you lower your taxable income. 

6. The Travel Points Strategy

Every business expense is an opportunity to earn rewards (ads, software, conferences).

A few foundational rules on credit card points: 

Rule 1: Never carry a balance (pay in full monthly)
Rule 2: Only use business cards for business expenses (don‚Äôt mix with personal)

For those who need to travel a lot, this often leads to massive savings. 

7. The Million-Dollar Mindset

W-2 workers ask: "How can I save $1k?"

Your biggest risk is never taking one.

Here's how to buy a biz, with less risk:

You can‚Äôt eliminate risk entirely.

But there are 3 M‚Äôs to remember:

- Minimization
- Mitigation
- Moderation

Here are tactical steps for each these phases to lower your risk of failure:

1. RISK MINIMIZATION (Deal Sourcing)

This is about finding a business that poses less risk to begin with.

Here are the 10 Value Markers we give our community members to weigh a biz‚Äôs risk:

- Financial Viability
- Diversification
- Employee-Centric Risk
- Owner-Centric Risk
- Cashflow vs Cashsuck
- Unfair Advantage
- Happy Customers / Reviews
- Recurring Revenue
- Upside Potential
- Documentation & Repeatable Processes

2. RISK MITIGATION (Negotiation)

This stage is about structuring the deal so you assume as little risk as possible.

A few quick tips:

- Don‚Äôt be greedy on your first deal, bring on other investors. It diversifies risk.
- Try to get seller financing. The seller is automatically incentivized to help you win.
- Tie some of the purchase price to work the seller will do with you over 1 year basis. (Seller Consultancy Contract)
- Tie some of the price to hitting xyz goals in the business. (Milestones & Earnouts)
- Hold cash in escrow until the biz hits the dollar amount it‚Äôs contracted to. (Holdbacks)
- Don‚Äôt have loan payments begin month 1. Give the business a quarter or two to stabilize without debt burden

3. RISK MODERATION (First 90 Days)

This is about how you control cash in the business once you're behind the wheel.

A few smart moves:

- Have on hand more cash than anticipated. Your biggest risk will always be running out of cash
- Partial acquisition. Before you buy an entire business, get partial ownership w/ a distributing equity. Gives you a chance to see behind the curtain
- Daily cashflow analysis. Watch your cash daily for the first 6 months to a year.
- Rolling cash flow statement. Make the business run on a cash basis first so you know your real cash on hand
- COA analysis. Use a model that analyzes up front if are you still cash flow positive if the business drops by 10-25-50%
- Subject matter expert. Ensure you are, you hired, or the business already has a good one.

Save this post.

Do these things.

And in theory, your likelihood of a failed acquisition drastically decreases.

These steps might lower your chances of a failed acquisition, but don't eliminate it entirely.

The same logic applies to running your biz‚Ä¶sometimes shit happens.

"You'll look back and wish you were a better dad than a businessman."

‚Äì My dad

If you do 1 thing a year as a father, make it:

A father daughter trip.

You can‚Äôt get back time. So this year we went off grid to far East Arizona...

Here‚Äôs 13 lessons from the road:

1. Take trips with your parents while you can. I told our uber driver that we were going on a father daughter trip, and she said, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs amazing, I wish my dad was still around.‚Äù Summarizes exactly why I do this trip each year.

2. So much knowledge is lost from one generation to the other, because we never asked. I learned this weekend more about hunting, fly fishing, tracking elk, and Arizona back countries than most will ever know.

3. Met a woman named Wink. She‚Äôs 85, runs the ranch and can ride a horse, bale hay and hike faster than almost any 30 year old I know. I‚Äôm starting to think we LET our bodies get old. Also I hope someone writes about me like they do her, ‚ÄúA woman with grit and cow sense‚Äù

4. Cowboys speak another language. We asked ‚ÄúWhere do the cows hang out mostly?‚Äù They said, ‚ÄúWell, reckon right about where they want.‚Äù We asked, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs your dog‚Äôs name?‚Äù She replied, ‚ÄúDog.‚Äù I like them.

5. Cats are metal as f when not domesticated. You ever seen a barn cat? Maybe we should have never let those little murderers into our homes.. they‚Äôre just biding their time.

6. Cows do not want to be snuggled. Turns out all those videos on Instagram of snuggling cows are a bunch of liars. I tried a few times. Results were not great. I repeat, do not attempt to snuggle a cow.

7. You‚Äôll never remember the things you never even tried. So, just try it.

8. We need more weekends without cell service as an option. When it‚Äôs not an option, it‚Äôs not a desire. Take a modern day service diet.

9. America is not found in urban cities. It‚Äôs found on the plains and the backwoods and the places with roads paved in dirt. They know all their neighbors, they count last names back in generations, they remember a fire or flood years ago‚Ä¶ they are builders. And they don‚Äôt ask for permission.

10. The more rugged you go, the more rugged you become. And that‚Äôs a good thing. Self sustainability, growing your own food, weathering storms‚Ä¶ there‚Äôs a reason Americans were tough.

11. Airbnb is not welcome here. Fast money, new people, not taking care of one another. Your bank account here is measured in impact not 0‚Äôs.

12. Mother nature is the ultimate antidepressant. There is just no way to not be in wonder while hiking a trail no man has before. While running into a beaver slapping his tail. While tracking an elk and bugling at him and he bugles back. Take a walk, get lost, get found.

Only two kinds of business exist:

1. Ones that take your money (cash-suck)
2. Ones that make you money (cash-flow)

Here are 14 actions to turn any cash-suck business into one that cash-flows:

First, what‚Äôs a cash-suck business?

‚Ä¢ You provide service, then get paid
‚Ä¢ You make money a few times a year
‚Ä¢ You have one big client (if they leave, you're toast)

Compare that to a cash-flow business:

‚Ä¢ You get paid, then provide service
‚Ä¢ You make monthly recurring revenue
‚Ä¢ You have lots of diverse clients

See how there‚Äôs a world of difference between the two?

Most businesses you buy will be cash-suck operations. Your goal in the first 90 days should be to turn that around.

I call it the Cash-Flow Boomerang Process.

Think of it as throwing out cash and having it fly back to you immediately:

1. Shorten your payment terms

Most businesses default to Net 30 payment terms because... that's what everyone else does.

Switch to Net 24 ( within 24 hours of completion). You can even go as far as taking 50% upfront.

First rule of business: don't work for free.

2. Get payment info from customers when they book

Have them sign a document that allows you to charge their card upon completion.

This one change removes the awkward "Where's my money?" conversation and speeds up your cash conversion cycle dramatically.

3. Offer discounts for cash payments

‚Ä¢ You avoid credit card fees (often 3-5%)
‚Ä¢ Customers love the discount
‚Ä¢ You get money instantly

This is literally a win-win for both sides and puts cash in your account faster.

4. Diversify your client base

When 1 client represents 15%+ of your revenue, that's not a business. It's a hostage situation, and you're the hostage.

I've seen businesses collapse because they lost their "whale client."

Diversify, or accept that you're a glorified employee.

5. Create recurring revenue

For any product or service you offer, ask: "Could this be a subscription?"

The answer is nearly always yes.

If you make most of your revenue from one season or event, your #1 priority should be creating year-round cash flow.

(For the rest of the list...go to the carousel!) 

Anyways, everybody knows most businesses fail within the first 5 years.

But how many realize 82% of those closures are due to cashflow issues?

That‚Äôs how important cash is.

You could be making money on paper while your bank account tells a different story.

The key to not becoming another statistic is simple, but not easy:

Don't run out of cash.

Revenue is vanity, profit is sanity, but cash is king.

Prioritize those metrics in that ascending order and you should be fine.
